definition: to deceive/to cheat
roar of laughter (onom.)/hubbub/to roar (as a crowd)
to deceive/to coax/to amuse (a child)
to cheat/to swindle/to deceive/to get on (a horse etc) by swinging one leg over

sentences.english: They have wheedled a holiday from the headmaster.
sentences.chinese: 他們哄騙校長而獲得了假日。

sentences.english: Some girls are coaxed into it by boy friends, or lure into it by predators.
sentences.chinese: 有些女孩這麼做或受男朋友哄騙，或受獵豔者引誘。

sentences.english: The manager deluded her into thinking he would give her the job.
sentences.chinese: 那經理哄騙她相信他會給她那份工作。

sentences.english: She's always palming the worst jobs off on her assistant.
sentences.chinese: 她總是哄騙她的助手做最無聊的工作。

sentences.english: Chinese editorials said South-East Asians should not be hoodwinked by imperialists.
sentences.chinese: 中方各大報紙表示東南亞各國不應讓帝國主義哄騙。

sentences.english: Young women were always interested in the trends of fashion, She was tricked to buy a scarf made of a triangular piece of blue silk.
sentences.chinese: 她被哄騙買了一條三角形的蘭色絲綢圍巾。

sentences.english: Nonetheless, our special cajoling has brought us success!
sentences.chinese: 不過，我們特殊的“哄騙”手段成功了。

sentences.english: They lulled me into a false sense of security.
sentences.chinese: 他們哄騙我，讓我產生了一種虛假的安全感。

sentences.english: They bamboozled him into joining the army.
To use PCs effectively, one must understand the capabilities of their operating systems software.
sentences.chinese: 爲了充分哄騙PC機，用戶必須瞭解操作系統的特徵。

sentences.english: He bamboozled me into exchanging the foreign currency.
He cheated his friends into the belief that he was an honest man.
sentences.chinese: 他哄騙友人相信他是個老實人。

sentences.english: He gulled us into buying rubbish.
sentences.chinese: 他哄騙我們購買毫無價值的東西。

sentences.english: Imagine someone's been diddling with our creations?
sentences.chinese: 想象有人在哄騙我們的作品？

sentences.english: That big boy is always cajoling other children into doing things for him.
sentences.chinese: 那個大男孩老是哄騙加緊的孩子爲他做事。

definition: to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to harbor evil designs/to harbor malicious intentions
spendthrift and foolish/sb with more money than sense
to shift one's eyes/(fig.) to shift one's attention/to divert attention
to dodge/to evade
lit. a deluge of heavenly flowers (idiom)/fig. extravagant embellishments/hype
indecisive/wavering
the trick of injuring oneself to gain the enemy's confidence/CL:條|条[tiao2]
to both be willing/mutual consent
variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
use both carrot and stick/use gentle methods and force/an iron hand in a velvet glove
to sow dissension (idiom); to drive a wedge between
to tell the truth/to tell it as it is
to go far/to escape to faraway places
to obstinately persist in going about things the wrong way (idiom)
strike first and gain the upper hand (idiom, martial arts term); Making the first move is an advantage.
